standard_metadata.standard_description: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.

question.content: Chika's uncle makes perfect brownies. Chika noted how much sugar he uses based on how many batches he makes:  Number of batches | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ :- | :-: | :-: | :-: **Sugar ($\text{kg}$)** | $0.6$ | $0.9$ | $1.2$  Chika has $2.25\,\text{kg}$ of sugar, and she wants to make as many batches as possible for a bake sale. She can make partial batches, and she has more than enough of the other ingredients.  **How many batches can Chika make?**   batches

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to find how much sugar makes $1$ batch. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how many batches we can make with $2.25\,\text{kg}$ of sugar.

###Unit rate and equation  Number of batches | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div2}$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: **Sugar ($\text{kg}$)** | $0.3$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div2}$ | $0.6$ | $0.9$ | $1.2$  Each batch uses $0.3\,\text{kg}$ of sugar, so we can write an equation to find the amount of sugar ($s$) in any number of batches ($b$):  $s=0.3b$  And we can rewrite the equation so the number of batches ($b$) is by itself:  $b=\dfrac{s}{0.3}$
###How many batches with $2.25\,\text{kg}$ of sugar?  Let's find the value of $b$ when $s=\blueE{2.25}$:  $\begin{align} b&=\dfrac{s}{0.3} \\\\ b&=\dfrac{\blueE{2.25}}{0.3} \\\\ b&=7.5 \end{align}$
###Answer  Chika can make $\boxed{7.5}$ batches with $2.25\,\text{kg}$ of sugar.

question.content: Morgan is visiting a city and wants to take a taxi. The driver tells Morgan that they charge per kilometer and shows this table describing their cost:  Distance ($\text{km}$) | $5$ | $10$ | $20$ :- | -: | -: | -: **Cost** | $\pounds 12.50$ | $\pounds 25$ | $\pounds 50$  Morgan needs to travel $13\,\text{km}$.  **How much will it cost Morgan to travel $13\,\text{km}$?**  $\pounds$

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to find how much it costs to travel $1\,\text{km}$. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how much it costs to travel $13\,\text{km}$.

###Unit rate and equation  Distance ($\text{km}$) | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div5}$ | $5$ | $10$ | $20$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: **Cost** | $\pounds 2.50$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div5}$ |$\pounds 12.50$ | $\pounds 25$ | $\pounds 50$  Each $1\,\text{km}$ costs $\pounds 2.50$, so we can write an equation to find the cost of a trip ($c$) based on how many kilometers it is ($k$):  $c=2.50k$
###Cost of $13\,\text{km}$ trip?  Let's find the value of $c$ when $k=\blueE{13}$:  $\begin{align} c&=2.50k \\\\ c&=2.50(\blueE{13}) \\\\ c&=32.5 \end{align}$
###Answer  It will cost Morgan $\pounds\boxed{32.50}$ for a $13\,\text{km}$ taxi trip.

question.content: Sasha is studying a type of coral that grows at a constant rate. Every month, she visits two pieces of the coral and measures their heights. She made this table:  Month | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ :- | -: | -: | -: Piece A's height (cm) | $24$ | $26$ | $28$ Piece B's height (cm) | $27$ | $29$ | $31$  **When Piece A's height is $49\,\text{cm}$, what will Piece B's height be?**   $\text{cm}$

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to think about the difference between Piece A's height and Piece B's height. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how tall Piece B is when Piece A is $49\,\text{cm}$ tall.

###Difference in heights and equation  Month | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ :- | -: | -: | -:  Piece A's height (cm) | $24$ | $26$ | $28$  | $\maroonE{\downarrow+3}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+3}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+3}$ Piece B's height (cm) | $27$ | $29$ | $31$  Piece B's height is always $3\,\text{cm}$ more than Pieace A's, so we can write an equation to find Piece B's height in terms of Piece A's:  $B=A+3$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]
###B's height when A's is $49\,\text{cm}$?  Let's find the value of $B$ when $A=\blueE{49}$:  $\begin{align} B&=A+3 \\\\ B&=\blueE{49}+3 \\\\ B&=52 \end{align}$
###Answer  Piece B's height will be $\boxed{52}\,\text{cm}$ when Piece A's height is $49\,\text{cm}$.

question.content: Lucia made this table to show the relationship between her age and her cousin Maria's age:  **Lucia's age (years)** | $8$ | $9$ | $10$ | $11$  :- | -: | -: | -: | -: **Maria's age (years)** | $14$ | $15$ | $16$ | $17$  **When Maria is $50$ years old, how old will Lucia be?**   years old

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to think about the difference between their ages. That will help us write an equation we can use to find Lucia's age when Maria is $50$ years old.

###Difference in ages and equation  **Lucia's age (years)** | $8$ | $9$ | $10$ | $11$  :- | -: | -: | -:   | $\maroonE{\uparrow-6}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow-6}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow-6}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow-6}$ **Maria's age (years)** | $14$ | $15$ | $16$ | $17$  Lucia's age is always $6$ years below Maria's age, so we can write an equation to find Lucia's age  ($L$) from Maria's age ($M$):  $L=M-6$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]
###Lucia's age when Maria is $50$  Let's find the value of $L$ when $M=\blueE{50}$:  $\begin{align} L&=M-6 \\\\ L&=\blueE{50}-6 \\\\ L&=44 \end{align}$
###Answer  Lucia will be $\boxed{44}$ years old when Maria is $50$ years old.

question.content: Miram is studying a type of plant that grows at a constant rate. Every month, she visits two of these plants and measures their heights. She made this table:  Week | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ :- | -: | -: | -: Plant A's height ($\text{cm}$) | $22$ | $24$ | $26$ Plant B's height ($\text{cm}$) | $26$ | $28$ | $30$  Miram wants an equation she can use to find Plant A's height in centimeters ($a$) given Plant B's height in centimeters ($b$).  **Complete Miram's equation.**  $a=$

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to think about the difference between Plant A's height and Plant B's height. That will help us write an equation we can use to find Plant A's height from  Plant B's height.

###Difference in heights and equation  Week | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ :- | -: | -: | -:  Plant A's height ($\text{cm}$) | $22$ | $24$ | $26$  | $\maroonE{\uparrow-4}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow-4}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow-4}$ Plant B's height ($\text{cm}$) | $26$ | $28$ | $30$  Plant A's height is always $4\,\text{cm}$ less than Plant B's, so we can write an equation to find Plant A's height in terms of Plant B's:  $a=b-4$
###Answer  Miram's equation is:   $a=b-4$

question.content: JosÃ© made this table to show the relationship between his age and his cousin Mario's age:  **JosÃ©'s age (years)** | $10$ | $11$ | $12$ | $13$  :- | -: | -: | -: | -: **Mario's age (years)** | $3$ | $4$ | $5$ | $6$  JosÃ© wants an equation he can use to find his own age ($j$) given Mario's age ($m$).  **Complete JosÃ©'s equation.**  $j=$

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to think about the difference between JosÃ© and Mario's ages. That will help us write an equation we can use to find JosÃ©'s age from Mario's age.

###Difference in ages and equation  **JosÃ©'s age (years)** | $10$ | $11$ | $12$ | $13$  :- | -: | -: | -: | -:  | $\maroonE{\uparrow+7}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow+7}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow+7}$ | $\maroonE{\uparrow+7}$ **Mario's age (years)** | $3$ | $4$ | $5$ | $6$  JosÃ©'s age is always $7$ years more than Mario's, so we can write an equation to find JosÃ©'s age in terms of Mario's age:  $j=m+7$
###Answer  JosÃ©'s equation is:   $j=m+7$

question.content: Nisha collects comic books, and she convinced her friend Hakim to start collecting as well. Every week, they go to the store together, and they each buy a new comic book. This table shows how many books they each have:  Week | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: Nisha | $10$ | $11$ | $12$ | $13$ Hakim | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$  Hakim wants an equation he can use to find how many comic books he will have ($h$) when Nisha has $n$ comic books.  **Complete Hakim's equation.**  $h=$

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to think about the difference between how many comic books Nisha and Hakim each have. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how many comic books Hakim has when we know how many comic books Nisha has.

###Difference and equation  Week | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: Nisha | $10$ | $11$ | $12$ | $13$  | $\maroonE{\downarrow-9}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow-9}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow-9}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow-9}$ Hakim | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$  Hakim always has $9$ fewer comic books than Nisha, so we can write an equation to find how many comic books Hakim has in terms of how many comic books Nisha has:  $h=n-9$
###Answer  Hakim's equation is:   $h=n-9$

question.content: Cameron collects old books, and they convinced their friend Kenji to start collecting as well. Every month, they go to the store together, and they each buy a book. This table shows how many books they each have:  Month | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: Kenji | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ Cameron | $12$ | $13$ | $14$ | $15$  They both want an equation they can use to find how many books Cameron will have ($c$) when Kenji has $k$ books.  **Complete their equation.**  $c=$

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the table to think about the difference between how many books Kenji and Cameron each have. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how many books Cameron has when we know how many books Kenji has.

###Difference and equation  Month | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: Kenji | $1$ | $2$ | $3$ | $4$  | $\maroonE{\downarrow+11}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+11}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+11}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+11}$ Cameron | $12$ | $13$ | $14$ | $15$  Cameron always has $11$ more books than Kenji, so we can write an equation to find how many books Cameron has in terms of how many books Kenji has:  $c=k+11$
###Answer  Their equation is:   $c=k+11$

question.content: Ryan made a graph to show how his age compared to his cat's age:    **When Ryan is $20$ years old, how old will his cat be?**   years old

images.alt: A graph plots r=Ryan's age in years on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 12, in increments of 2, versus c=Cat's age in years on the vertical axis, from 0 to 12, in increments of 2, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (6, 1), (8, 3), and (10, 5).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the graph to think about the difference between Ryan's age and his cat's age. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how old Ryan's cat will be when Ryan is $20$ years old.

###Difference in ages and equation  **Ryan's age** | $6$ | $8$ | $10$ :- | -: | -: | -:   | $\maroonE{\downarrow-5}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow-5}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow-5}$ **Cat's age** | $1$ | $3$ | $5$  The cat's age is always $5$ years less than Ryan's age, so we can write an equation to find the cat's age ($c$) in terms of Ryan's age ($r$):  $c=r-5$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]
###How old is the cat when Ryan is $20$?  Let's find the value of $c$ when $r=\blueE{20}$:  $\begin{align} c&=r-5 \\\\ c&=\blueE{20}-5 \\\\ c&=15 \end{align}$
###Answer  When Ryan is $20$ years old, his cat will be $\boxed{15}$ years old.

question.content: Hien made a graph to show how her age compared to her turtle's age:    **When Hien is $25$ years old, how old will her turtle be?**   years old

images.alt: A graph plots h=Hien's age in years on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 20, in increments of 2, versus t=Turtle's age in years on the vertical axis, from 0 to 20, in increments of 2, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (6, 14), (8, 16), and (10, 18).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the graph to think about the difference between Hien's age and her turtle's age. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how old Hien's turtle will be when Hien is $25$ years old.

###Difference in ages and equation  **Hien's age** | $6$ | $8$ | $10$ :- | -: | -: | -:   | $\maroonE{\downarrow+8}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+8}$ | $\maroonE{\downarrow+8}$ **Turtle's age** | $14$ | $16$ | $18$  The turtle's age is always $8$ years more than Hien's age, so we can write an equation to find the turtle's age ($t$) in terms of Hien's age ($h$):  $t=h+8$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]
###How old is the turtle when Hien is $25$?  Let's find the value of $t$ when $h=\blueE{25}$:  $\begin{align} t&=h+8 \\\\ t&=\blueE{25}+8 \\\\ t&=33 \end{align}$
###Answer  When Hien is $25$ years old, her turtle will be $\boxed{33}$ years old.

question.content: Iliana plays a video game that awards experience points, called "XP", based on how long she plays. She made this graph to study how her playing time relates to XP:    **How many hours will it take Iliana to get $200$ total XP?**   hours

images.alt: A graph plots t=playing time in hours on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 7, in increments of 1, versus p=total XP on the vertical axis, from 0 to 80, in increments of 10, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (2, 25), (4, 50), and (6, 75).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the graph to find how much XP Iliana gets in $1$ hour. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how long it will take her to get $200$ XP.

###Unit rate and equation  Playing time (hours) | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div2}$ | $2$ | $4$ | $6$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: **Total XP** | $12.5$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div2}$ | $25$ | $50$ | $75$  So Iliana gains $12.5$ XP for playing the game for $1$ hour, and we can write an equation to find how much XP Iliana gains ($p$) for any number of hours of playing time ($t$):  $p=12.5t$  And we can rewrite the equation so time ($t$) is by itself:  $t=\dfrac{p}{12.5}$
###How long to gain $200$ total XP?  Let's find the value of $t$ when $p=\blueE{200}$:  $\begin{align} t&=\dfrac{p}{12.5} \\\\ t&=\dfrac{\blueE{200}}{12.5} \\\\ t&=16 \end{align}$
###Answer  It will take Iliana $\boxed{16}$ hours to gain $200$ total XP.

question.content: Hector plays a video game that awards gems based on how long he plays. He made this graph to study how his playing time relates to number of gems:    **How many total gems will Hector get if he plays for $10.5$ hours?**   gems

images.alt: A graph plots t=playing time in hours on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 7, in increments of 1, versus g=total gems on the vertical axis, from 0 to 48, in increments of 8, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (2, 16), (4, 32), and (6, 48).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the graph to find how many gems Hector gets in $1$ hour. That will help us write an equation we can use to find how many gems he gets for playing $10.5$ hours.

###Unit rate and equation  Playing time (hours) | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div2}$ | $2$ | $4$ | $6$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: **Total gems** | $8$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div2}$ | $16$ | $32$ | $48$  So Hector gets $8$ gems for playing the game for $1$ hour, and we can write an equation to find how many gems Hector gets ($g$) for any number of hours of playing time ($t$):  $g=8t$  [[â˜ƒ explanation 1]]
###How many gems in $10.5$ hours?  Let's find the value of $g$ when $t=\blueE{10.5}$:  $\begin{align} g&=8t \\\\ t&=8 (\blueE{10.5}) \\\\ t&=84 \end{align}$
###Answer  Hector will get $\boxed{84}$ gems if he plays for $10.5$ hours.

question.content: Amari is researching an electric car. He finds this graph, which shows how much range, measured in kilometers, the car gains based on charging time:    Amari wants an equation he can use to find how much charging time ($t$) it takes to gain any number of kilometers in range ($k$).  **Complete Amari's equation.**  $t=$

images.alt: A graph plots t=charging time in minutes on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 30, in increments of 10, versus k=range gain on the vertical axis, from 0 to 500, in increments of 100, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (10, 150), (20, 300), and (30, 450).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the data in the graph to find how much range is gained from $1$ minute of charging. Then, we can write an equation to find how much charging time ($t$) it takes to gain any number of kilometers in range ($k$).

###Unit rate and equation  [[â˜ƒ image 1]]  $t$ | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div10}$ | $10$ | $20$ | $30$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: $k$ | $15$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div10}$ | $150$ | $300$ | $450$  The electric car gains $15\,\text{km}$ of range for every $1$ minute of charging, so we can write an equation to find how many kilometers of range the car gains ($k$) for any number of minutes it charges ($t$):  $k=15t$  And we can rewrite the equation so time ($t$) is by itself:  $t=\dfrac{k}{15}$

images.alt: A graph plots t=charging time in minutes on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 30, in increments of 10, versus k=range gain on the vertical axis, from 0 to 500, in increments of 100, on a coordinate plane.  Points are plotted and labeled as follows: (10, 150), (20, 300), and (30, 450).

hints.content: ###Answer  Amari's equation is:   $t=\dfrac{k}{15}$

question.content: Leo is researching an electric bicycle. He finds this graph, which shows how much range, measured in kilometers, the bicycle gains based on charging time:    Leo wants an equation he can use to find how many kilometers of range the bicycle gains ($k$) based on how many minutes it charges ($t$).  **Complete Leo's equation.**  $k=$

images.alt: A graph plots t=charging time in minutes on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 20, in increments of 5, versus k=range gain on the vertical axis, from 0 to 70, in increments of 10, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (5, 20), (10, 40), and (15, 60).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the data in the graph to find how much range is gained from $1$ minute of charging. Then, we can write an equation to find how many kilometers of range the bicycle gains ($k$) based on how many minutes it charges ($t$).

###Unit rate and equation  [[â˜ƒ image 1]]  $t$ | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div5}$ | $5$ | $10$ | $15$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: $k$ | $4$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div5}$ | $20$ | $40$ | $60$  The electric bicycle gains $4\,\text{km}$ of range for every $1$ minute of charging, so we can write an equation to find how many kilometers of range the bicycle gains ($k$) for any number of minutes it charges ($t$):  $k=4t$

images.alt: A graph plots t=charging time in minutes on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 20, in increments of 5, versus k=range gain on the vertical axis, from 0 to 70, in increments of 10, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted and labeled as follows: (5, 20), (10, 40), and (15, 60).

hints.content: ###Answer  Leo's equation is:  $k=4t$

question.content: Chris is studying a type of coral that grows at a constant rate. They measured the age and height of $3$ pieces of the coral. Here's what they found:    Chris wants an equation they can use to find the height in centimeters ($h$) of any piece of this coral based on its age in years ($a$).  **Complete Chris' equation.**  $h=$

images.alt: A graph plots a=age in years, from 0 to 7 on the horizontal axis, in increments of 1, versus h=height in centimeters on the vertical axis, from 0 to 50, in increments of 5, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (2, 15), (4, 30), and (6, 45).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the data in the graph to find the height of this type of coral when its age is $1$ year. Since the coral grows at a constant rate, we can then write an equation to find its height ($h$) at any age ($a$).

###Unit rate and equation  [[â˜ƒ image 1]]  $a$ | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div 2}$ | $2$ | $4$ | $6$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: $h$ | $7.5$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div 2}$ | $15$ | $30$ | $45$  The coral's height grows $7.5\,\text{cm}$ every $1$ year, so we can write an equation to find the height ($h$) at any age ($a$):  $h=7.5a$

images.alt: A graph plots a=age in years, from 0 to 7 on the horizontal axis, in increments of 1, versus h=height in centimeters on the vertical axis, from 0 to 50, in increments of 5, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted and labeled as follows: (2, 15), (4, 30), and (6, 45).

hints.content: ###Answer  Chris' equation is:  $h=7.5a$

question.content: Noah is studying a type of sea sponge that grows at a constant rate. They measured the age and height of $3$ pieces of the sponge. Here's what they found:    Noah wants an equation they can use to find the age, in years, ($a$) of any piece of this sponge based on its height in centimeters ($h$).  **Complete Noah's equation.**  $a=$

images.alt: A graph plots a=age in years, from 0 to 12, in increments of 2, versus h=height in centimeters, from 0 to 24, in increments of 4, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (4, 8), (8, 16), and (10, 20).

hints.content: ###Strategy  Let's use the data in the graph to find the height of this sponge when its age is $1$ year. Since the sponge grows at a constant rate, we can then write an equation to find its age ($a$) from its height ($h$).

###Unit rate and equation  [[â˜ƒ image 1]]  $a$ | $1$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div 4}$ | $4$ | $8$ | $10$ :- | -: | -: | -: | -: | -: $h$ | $2$ | $\maroonE{\leftarrow \div 4}$ | $15$ | $30$ | $45$  The sea sponges's height grows $2\,\text{cm}$ every $1$ year, so we can write an equation to find the height ($h$) at any age ($a$):  $h=2a$  And we can rewrite the equation so age ($a$) is by itself:  $a=\dfrac{h}{2}$

images.alt: A graph plots a=age in years on the horizontal axis, from 0 to 12, in increments of 2, versus h=height in centimeters on the vertical axis, from 0 to 24, in increments of 4, on a coordinate plane. Points are plotted as follows: (4, 8), (8, 16), and (10, 20).

hints.content: ###Answer  Noah's equation is:  $a=\dfrac{h}{2}$
